title: Symposium:  Bijinga—Japanese Interpretations of Beauty in Ukiyo-e
description:
This one-day symposium will explore the many layers of meaning embodied in paintings of beauties (bijinga) by Japanese artists of the Edo and Meiji periods by examining the cultural and social forces that gave rise to and sustained ukiyo-e (pictures of the floating world) in premodern Japan. In particular, the talks will highlight the impetus to classify beauty in its various forms and to deepen its content through calligraphic inscriptions and carefully chosen painting techniques and mountings. The state of the field of scholarship on ukiyo-e paintings as well as collecting practices will be assessed, allowing for a reevaluation of the relevance of bijinga in our contemporary society where ideals of beauty are both valued and questioned.
